column1: #text=Physalis ( /ˈfaɪsəlɪs/ , sometimes /faɪˈseɪlɪs/)[2 ] is a genus of flowering plants in the nightshade family ( Solanaceae ) , which grow in warm temperate and subtropical regions of the world . Most of the species , of which there may be 75-90 , are indigenous to the New World with one notable exception ( P. alkekengi ) . Cultivated species and weedy annuals have been introduced worldwide . A notable feature is the formation of a large papery husk derived from the calyx , which partly or fully encloses the fruit , . [ 3 ] The fruit is small and orange , similar in size , shape and structure to a small tomato
#text=At least 46 species are endemic to the country of Mexico . [ 4

#text=Many Physalis species are called groundcherries . [ 5 ] One name for Physalis peruviana is Cape gooseberry , not to be confused with the true gooseberries , which are of the genus Ribes in the family Grossulariaceae . Another name used to refer to the fruit is simply golden berries . [ 6
